abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the National
            Agricultural and Livestock Research Project is rated
            satisfactory, is likely sustainable, and achieved the
            objectives of structural consolidation and institutional
            reform. Bank performance was satisfactory while borrower
            performance was mixed, initially poor but eventually good as
            management improved and innovative decisions began to take
            hold. Lessons learned include: a) the new development
            function must be clearly defined and explained; b) client
            oriented research approaches must be fully integrated in
            commodity and cross cutting programs along with further
            training and support; c) livestock research deserves
            strengthening; d) chronic financial constraints can generate
            improved and innovative management approaches to mitigate
            funding problems; e) expenditures on Technical Assistance
            should be very selective and their quality and utility
            carefully monitored; f) decentralization of management and
            administration is strongly supported, although imaginative
            coordination is needed; g) a statutory framework should be
            established for cess-funded commodity research; h) retention
            of competent and motivated management is essential for
            effectiveness; i) the National Agricultural Research Fund
            mandate will require review in light of lessons learned from
            the Zonal Agricultural Research Funds; and j)
            research-extension-farmer linkages improved overtime and
            were helped by allocations made in extension projects.
